thread.title: Lamar's turnaround propelled by win over McNeese St.
thread.title_full: Lamar's turnaround propelled by win over McNeese St.

author: Danny Shapiro
title: Lamar's turnaround propelled by win over McNeese St.
text:
Close Image 1 of 4 Lamar wide receiver Jayce Nelson runs into the end zone for a touchdown against McNeese State. The Cardinals won their season finale 27-24. Lamar wide receiver Jayce Nelson runs into the end zone for a touchdown against McNeese State. The Cardinals won their season finale 27-24. Photo: Kyle Ezell Image 2 of 4 Lamar wide receiver Mark Roberts looks for more yardage in the Cardinals season finale against McNeese State. Lamar won the game 27-24 on a game-winning field goal. Lamar wide receiver Mark Roberts looks for more yardage in the Cardinals season finale against McNeese State. Lamar won the game 27-24 on a game-winning field goal. Photo: Kyle Ezell Image 3 of 4 Lamar quarterback Caleb Berry scrambles in search of more yardage against McNeese State. The Cardinals won the game 27-24 on a last-second, game-winning field goal. Lamar quarterback Caleb Berry scrambles in search of more yardage against McNeese State. The Cardinals won the game 27-24 on a last-second, game-winning field goal. Photo: Kyle Ezell Image 4 of 4 Lamar teammates share a hug after the Cardinals defeated McNeese State 27-24 on Saturday, November 22. Lamar teammates share a hug after the Cardinals defeated McNeese State 27-24 on Saturday, November 22. Photo: Kyle Ezell Lamar's turnaround propelled by win over McNeese St. 1 / 4 Back to Gallery 
When Kade Harrington locked arms with his Lamar teammates before Juan Carranco 's game-winning field goal against No. 17 McNeese State last season, he knew things were about to change. 
Carranco's field goal sailed through the uprights, and the Cardinals sailed to their best season since the program's 2010 resurrection, finishing with eight wins and a victory over the rival Cowboys for the first time. 
The McNeese State game was the tipping point for a Lamar football program growing out of its naive youth into early adulthood. 
The days of being content with having football back and winning four games a season ended that day. 
"It was such an incredible feeling," Harrington said. "We proved we could not only play with the big boys in the conference but that we could beat them. It was big for us." 
Last January, when Harrington and the Cardinals returned to team activities, the energy that shone through against McNeese State was still present. 
Players were buzzing about their program's progress - there was talk about being yearly contenders in the Southland Conference and winning a conference championship sooner rather than later. 
Senior wide receiver Reggie Begelton , entering his fifth and final season, was one of those players who noticed a different attitude. 
"That win over McNeese really opened our eyes," Begelton said. "Our confidence went way up, and momentum started rolling. That's what us winning that game did." 
Even when Lamar was picked eighth this season in the Southland preseason poll, Begelton and the Cardinals didn't flinch. 
At Southland Conference media day in July, Begelton answered question after question about the polls, reinforcing that the Cardinals were the team that knocked off McNeese State, not the team people saw from 2010-2013. 
Discounting last week's slip-up against Northwestern State, the Cardinals have exhibited all of the signs of the team that showed up at McNeese State. 
Lamar hung tough against Baylor, ranked No. 2 in the Football Bowl Subdivision, then beat Sam Houston State, at the time No. 3 in the Football Championship Subdivision, for the first time and narrowly lost to two-time defending Southland Conference champion Southeastern Louisiana on the road. 
"Our expectations entering this season were higher," Cardinals head coach Ray Woodard said. "We finally figured out the difference between wanting to win big games and actually winning big games because of McNeese." 
Even former players, like wide receiver Mark Roberts , have noticed Lamar's change in attitude. 
Roberts' last college game was the victory over McNeese State. 
"I saw it on my way out and I've seen it this year," Roberts said. "The guys are playing with a different swagger now. They're playing like they can't use the excuse of 'Oh, we're a new program' anymore." 
Lamar's 2-2 conference record is good for a fourth-place tie. With Central Arkansas and McNeese State, two teams leading the Cardinals, among their last five opponents, there's time for improvement. 
Woodard isn't worried about his team's psyche. As a coach, that's all he can ask for. 
"I'm not sure how these last five games will go," Woodard said. "But what I do know is that these guys won't give up. They're a fun group to coach, more mature than they've been in the past and have put us on the right track."
